content.text: Once upon a time, in a lush green forest where the trees stretched tall and the sun dappled the ground with golden light, there lived a clever fox named Reynard.
Reynard was known far and wide for his sly ways and his knack for getting what he wanted—often without much effort at all.
One bright morning, as Reynard trotted through the forest in search of breakfast, his nose twitched at the most delicious smell. It was rich, savory, and oh-so-tempting.
Following the scent, he looked up and saw a plump, glossy crow perched on a high branch of an old oak tree. In her beak, she held a large, golden piece of cheese—stolen, no doubt, from some
unsuspecting farmer’s kitchen. Reynard’s mouth watered at the sight. "Oh, what a fine breakfast that would make," he thought. But how could he get it?
The crow was high above, and foxes, as clever as they are, cannot fly. Then, an idea sparked in Reynard’s mind. He sat down beneath the tree, tilted his head back, and gazed up at the crow with his
most charming smile. "Good morning, dear Madam Crow!" he called in his smoothest voice. "What a glorious day it is, is it not?"
The crow, who had been enjoying her prize in peace, glanced down at the fox but said nothing. She knew better than to trust a fox’s sweet words. Undeterred, Reynard continued.
"I must say, Madam Crow, you are looking particularly radiant today. Your feathers are so sleek and black, like the night sky itself. And your eyes—they sparkle like the brightest stars!"
The crow shifted on her branch, her grip on the cheese tightening just a little. She had never been called radiant before. Reynard pressed on. "But what truly takes my breath away is your voice!

I have heard that you possess the most beautiful singing voice in all the forest. Oh, how I long to hear it! Would you do me the great honor of singing just one little song?" Now, the crow was no fool.
She knew that flattery often came with a price. But oh, how sweet it was to hear such kind words! No one had ever praised her voice before. Perhaps, just this once, she could show off her talent.
With a deep breath, the crow opened her beak wide—and out tumbled the golden cheese, right into Reynard’s waiting paws below. "Ah, thank you, dear Madam Crow!"
Reynard exclaimed, catching the cheese in his mouth. "Your voice is indeed as lovely as your feathers—though I must say, your judgment is not quite as sharp!"
And with that, the sly fox trotted away, leaving the crow perched in the tree, her heart heavy with regret. She had been tricked by pretty words, and now her breakfast was gone.
From that day on, the crow learned to be wary of flattery. And as for Reynard? Well, he enjoyed his cheese that morning, chuckling to himself about how easily he had outsmarted the crow.
But remember, little one, not all that glitters is gold, and not all who speak sweetly have kind intentions. Always think before you act, and never let pride cloud your judgment.
Now, close your eyes and dream of forests and clever foxes—but don’t let them steal your cheese!
